earliestArticle.dc:abstract: Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetically heterogeneous, autosomal-recessive disorder, characterized by oto-sino-pulmonary disease and situs abnormalities. PCD-causing mutations have been identified in 20 genes, but collectively they account for only ∼65% of all PCDs. To identify mutations in additional genes that cause PCD, we performed exome sequencing on three unrelated probands with ciliary outer and inner dynein arm (ODA+IDA) defects. Mutations in SPAG1 were identified in one family with three affected siblings. Further screening of SPAG1 in 98 unrelated affected individuals (62 with ODA+IDA defects, 35 with ODA defects, 1 without available ciliary ultrastructure) revealed biallelic loss-of-function mutations in 11 additional individuals (including one sib-pair). All 14 affected individuals with SPAG1 mutations had a characteristic PCD phenotype, including 8 with situs abnormalities. Additionally, all individuals with mutations who had defined ciliary ultrastructure had ODA+IDA defects. SPAG1 was present in human airway epithelial cell lysates but was not present in isolated axonemes, and immunofluorescence staining showed an absence of ODA and IDA proteins in cilia from an affected individual, thus indicating that SPAG1 probably plays a role in the cytoplasmic assembly and/or trafficking of the axonemal dynein arms. Zebrafish morpholino studies of spag1 produced cilia-related phenotypes previously reported for PCD-causing mutations in genes encoding cytoplasmic proteins. Together, these results demonstrate that mutations in SPAG1 cause PCD with ciliary ODA+IDA defects and that exome sequencing is useful to identify genetic causes of heterogeneous recessive disorders.
earliestArticle.dc:creator: Knowles MR
earliestArticle.dc:title: Mutations in SPAG1 cause primary ciliary dyskinesia associated with defective outer and inner dynein arms.

evidence.dc:description: Immunoblot analysis of SPAG1 and DNAI1 (known ciliary gene) was performed on undifferentiated and differentiated human airway epithelial cells and also in isolated cilia.  Hybridization with a SPAG1 antibody shows expression of full length SPAG1 (as a well as a slightly smaller isoform) in differentiated respiratory epithelial whole cell lysates but not in ciliary axonemes or undifferentiated respiratory epithelial cell lysates.  A much smaller isoform of SPAG1, characterized more fully by Smith et al 2022 (PMID:35178554) and identified as a 60kDa protein translated from an alternative downstream "atg" in exon 11, is seen in both undifferentiated and differentiated respiratory cells, but also not in cilia.  DNAI1, is as expected, only seen in differentiated cells and in cilia.  The expression of full length SPAG1 in differentiated human respiratory epithelial cells, but not in the ciliary axoneme is consistent with a role of full length SPAG1 in the cytoplasmic pre-assembly of dynein arm complexes in the respiratory epithelial cell.  The expression of a small SPAG1 isomer in both differentiated and undifferentiated cells, indicates the possibility of this SPAG1 isomer playing a different, perhaps additional cellular role, but does not contradict the specific role that full length SPAG1 is thought to play in the assembly or transport of dynein arms in ciliated cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression of SPAG1 during airway cell ciliogenesis

evidence.dc:description: Immunoblots on whole-cell lysates from human nasal multiciliated epithelial cells were preformed using an antibody that targets the C terminus of SPAG1.  The full length  and a 94-kDa isoform of SPAG1 were absent in three PCD patients with biallelic SPAG1 mutations (Patients  UNC-372 III-1, UNC-68 III-2  and UNC-1231 II-10), but present in control samples.  However, a 60-kDa band was present in subjects UNC-68 III-2, UNC-1231 II-10, and controls but absent in UNC-372 III-1 protein cell lysates.  Immunoblots using an N terminus SPAG1 antibody detected only full length and 94-kDa isoforms in control lysate and no isoforms in UNC-68 III-2 and UNC-372 cell lysates.  The absence of the full length SPAG1 is consistent with the absence of outer and inner dynein arms and ciliary immotility in PCD patients with SPAG1 mutations, as SPAG1 is hypothesized to play a role in dynein arm assembly.  The presence of a 60-kDa SPAG1 isoform that still contains two TPR domains and the RPAP3_C domain and is thought to retain some dynein arm assembly function, is consistent with the atypical PCD phenotype seen in individuals UNC-68 III-2  and UNC-1231 II-10 that display some ciliary motility and retain some outer dynein arms.  Transcript analysis of this 60-kDA isoform confirms that a downstream alternative ATG translation start site is used to produce this constitutively expressed 545-amino acid protein.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Mutations in SPAG1, a dynein axonemal assembly factor (DNAAF) that facilitates the assembly of dynein arms in the cytoplasm before their transport into the cilium, result in primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a genetically heterogenous disorder characterized by chronic oto-sino-pulmonary disease, infertility and laterality defects. To further elucidate the role of SPAG1 in dynein assembly, we examined its expression, interactions and ciliary defects in control and PCD human airway epithelia. Immunoprecipitations showed that SPAG1 interacts with multiple DNAAFs, dynein chains and canonical components of the R2TP complex. Protein levels of dynein heavy chains (DHCs) and interactions between DHCs and dynein intermediate chains (DICs) were reduced in SPAG1 mutants. We also identified a previously uncharacterized 60 kDa SPAG1 isoform, through examination of PCD subjects with an atypical ultrastructural defect for SPAG1 variants, that can partially compensate for the absence of full-length SPAG1 to assemble a reduced number of outer dynein arms. In summary, our data show that SPAG1 is necessary for axonemal dynein arm assembly by scaffolding R2TP-like complexes composed of several DNAAFs that facilitate the folding and/or binding of the DHCs to the DIC complex.
dc:source.dc:creator: Smith AJ
dc:source.dc:title: The role of SPAG1 in the assembly of axonemal dyneins in human airway epithelia.

evidence.rdfs:label: SPAG1 Protein expression in PCD-affected individuals

evidence.dc:description: The cytoplasmic folding and pre-assembly of dynein arm proteins into larger complexes takes place in a stepwise manner involving interactions with various DNAAFs (Dynein Axonemal Assembly Factors), chaperones, and co-chaperones (PMID: 31817850). SPAG1 has been hypothesized to be one of many DNAAFs that interact to form dynein arm complexes in ciliated cells (PMID: 30561330). Immunoprecipitation of SPAG1 using SPAG1 antibody shows that SPAG1 interacts with dynein chains DNAH6 and DNAH5.  Other previously identified DNAAFs that also co-precipitate with SPAG1 include DNAAF2, PIH1D2, DNAAF1, RPAP3, DNAAF10 (WDR92), DNAAF3, RUVBL1 AND RUVB2.  RPAP3, DNAAF10, RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 are components of the R2TP/Prefoldin-like complex, a HSP90 co-chaperone complex involved in the assembly process of many molecular machines. All of these protein interactions identified by immunoprecipitation are consistent with SPAG1's involvement in axonemal dynein arm assembly.  Of note: immunoprecipitation with a C terminus specific SPAG1 antibody also identified DNAH9 and DNAI1 (dyneins) as interactors of SPAG1 as well as components of the chaperonin CCT (HSPA4 and HSPH1).
evidence.rdfs:label: SPAG1 interacts with DNAAFs, dyneins, co-chaperone complex

evidence.dc:description: Ciliary motility is driven by a molecular motor composed of both inner and outer dynein arms, that are multi-protein complexes made up of dozens of proteins. Pre-assembly of these arms requires many protein factors including the R2SP complex, a co-chaperone complex of which SPAG1 is a key component (PMID: 29844425). The R2SP complex is proposed to work together with HSP70 and HSP90 to facilitate the quaternary structure organization of the dynein arms.  The PCD phenotype of absent inner and outer dynein arms and immotile cilia is consistent with a defect in SPAG1 that prevents this complex from completing its role in dynein arm assembly..

dc:source.dc:abstract: In cells, many constituents are able to assemble resulting in large macromolecular machineries possessing very specific biological and physiological functions, e.g. ribosome, spliceosome and proteasome. Assembly of such entities is commonly mediated by transient protein factors. SPAG1 is a multidomain protein, known to participate in the assembly of both the inner and outer dynein arms. These arms are required for the function of sensitive and motile cells. Together with RUVBL1, RUVBL2 and PIH1D2, SPAG1 is a key element of R2SP, a protein complex assisting the quaternary assembly of specific protein clients in a tissue-specific manner and associating with heat shock proteins (HSPs) and regulators. In this study, we have investigated the role of TPR domains of SPAG1 in the recruitment of HSP chaperones by combining biochemical assays, ITC, NMR spectroscopy and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. First, we propose that only two, out of the three TPR domains, are able to recruit the protein chaperones HSP70 and HSP90. We then focused on one of these TPR domains and elucidated its 3D structure using NMR spectroscopy. Relying on an NMR-driven docking approach and MD simulations, we deciphered its binding interface with the C-terminal tails of both HSP70 and HSP90. Finally, we addressed the biological function of SPAG1 and specifically demonstrated that a SPAG1 sub-fragment, containing a putative P-loop motif, cannot efficiently bind and hydrolyze GTP
dc:source.dc:creator: Chagot ME
dc:source.dc:title: Binding properties of the quaternary assembly protein SPAG1.

evidence.rdfs:label: SPAG1 TPR domains interact with chaperones HSP70 and HSP90

evidence.dc:description: Transmission electron microscopy of nasal cilia from patient UNC-372 III-1 shows a loss of both outer and inner dynein arms.  Transmission electron microscopy of nasal cilia from patients UNC-68 III-2  and UNC-1231 II-1 show few if any inner dynein arms, but many normal outer dynein arms present. Additionally, immunofluorescence to further characterize cilia structure in the respiratory epithelial cells of these patients cells showed an absence of DNAH5 and DNAI1 (outer dynein arm components)  and an absence of the inner dynein arm component DNALI1 in patient UNC-372 III-1. Patients UNC-68 III-2  and UNC-1231 II-1 have no DNALI1 staining the inner dynein arms while DNAI1 and DNAH5 were present along the full length of the ciliary axoneme, albeit at a reduced level compared to control cilia, confirming the absence of inner dynein arms and the presence of outer dynein arms. Patients UNC-68 III-2  and UNC-1231 II-1 also retain some ciliary motility (most SPAG1 variant patients have immotile cilia). In summary, the absence or reduction of these dyneins suggests a disruption of outer and inner dynein arm assembly in the airway of patients carrying SPAG1 mutations. The atypical SPAG1 PCD ciliary phenotype seen in patients UNC-68 III-2  and UNC-1231 II-1 is thought to be due to the expression of a previously uncharacterized 60-kDa isoform of SPAG1 that may be compensating for lack of full length SPAG1 and can assemble some normal ODAs. Patient UNC-372 III-1 shows a loss of the 60-kDa isoform, while UNC-68 III-2  and UNC-1231 retain expression of this 60-kDa isoform. These data, while complex,  are consistent with SPAG1 assisting in the cytoplasmic assembly of axonemal dyneins.
evidence.rdfs:label: Structural defects in respiratory cilia from SPAG1 patients

evidence.dc:description: The cilia related phenotypes seen in these zebrafish morpholinos have previously been noted in other zebrafish models of PCD-causing mutations that encode cytoplasmic proteins (DNAAF3, LRRC50, LRRC6).  Zebrafish have motile cilia in the left-right organizer (Kupffer's vesicle), the spinal canal, pronephric ducts, brain ventricles, and olfactory placode.  The defects seen in zebrafish when spag1 is knocked down using morpholinos (dorsal body axis curvature and hydrocephalus) are consistent with the phenotype one might see in zebrafish with defective motile cilia. These phenotypes are also consistent with the human SPAG1 mutations that result in ciliary immotility in respiratory cells resulting in respiratory symptoms and the immotile nodal cilia that cause laterality defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: SPAG1 Ortholog Morpholino Knockdown in Zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Morpholino knockdown comes with the risk of potential  "off-target" effects.  For this reason, the default score has been downscored to 1.

Male infertility, immotile sperm, the loss of auditory/vibration mechanotransduction in Ch neurons (impaired larval hearing), and defective adult proprioception in SPAG1 depleted Drosophila mutants are phenotypes consistent with the human SPAG1 mutations that result in ciliary immotility in respiratory cells resulting in respiratory symptoms and immotile nodal cilia that lead to laterality defects. This study concludes that CG18472/Spag1 likely conserves the dynein assembly function of human SPAG1.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The massive dynein motor complexes that drive ciliary and flagellar motility require cytoplasmic preassembly, a process requiring dedicated dynein assembly factors (DNAAFs). How DNAAFs interact with molecular chaperones to control dynein assembly is not clear. By analogy with the well-known multifunctional HSP90-associated cochaperone, R2TP, several DNAAFs have been suggested to perform novel R2TP-like functions. However, the involvement of R2TP itself (canonical R2TP) in dynein assembly remains unclear. Here we show that in
dc:source.dc:creator: Zur Lage P
dc:source.dc:title: Ciliary dynein motor preassembly is regulated by Wdr92 in association with HSP90 co-chaperone, R2TP.

evidence.rdfs:label: Drosophila CG18472/Spag1 RNAi knockdown

evidence.dc:description: NM_003114.5(SPAG1):c.2T>G (p.Met1Arg) is a missense mutation in the translation start site that is predicted to interfere with SPAG1 translation.
Downscored to 1 because while the initiation codon has been lost, the authors provide no data to exclude the possibility of the use of a different in-frame start codon with a functional product.

NC_000008.11:g.100151617_100163589del is an 11,971 bp deletion that includes the 5' part of SPAG1 (including the start codon of SPAG1 and part of intron 2), and upstream regions including the 3' end of the proximal gene POLR2K (including stop codon) and the intergenic region. 
POLR2K=RNA POLYMERASE II, 7-KD SUBUNIT

Knowles et al were unable to identify other POLR2K mutations in this individual, suggesting that the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern of PCD in this family is due to the two SPAG1 variants.  They have not, however eliminated the possibility that the deleted 3' region of POLR2K is responsible for a PCD phenotype. For this reason the score has been reduced to 1.

evidence.detectionMethod: Segregation analyses were performed in family members

dc:source.dc:abstract: To report detailed knowledge about the clinical manifestations, ciliary phenotypes, genetic spectrum as well as phenotype/genotype correlation in primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) in Chinese children.
dc:source.dc:creator: Guo Z
dc:source.dc:title: Clinical and Genetic Spectrum of Children with Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia in China.

evidence.rdfs:label: P50

evidence.dc:description: NM_003114.5(SPAG1):c.691del is a frameshift mutation that replaces Tyr231 with Ile and a termination signal 12 amino acids downstream, either leading to NMD or producing a 75% truncated protein.
NM_003114.5(SPAG1):c.1650dup is a frameshift mutation that replaces Asp551 with Arg and a termination signal 9 amino acids downstream, either leading to NMD or producing a 40% truncated protein.

evidence.detectionMethod: Variants were identified by Sanger sequencing.  Probands were also screened for for a specific 12kb large deletion by PCR and subsequently confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNC-372 III-1 (#1391)

evidence.dc:description: NM_003114.5(SPAG1):c.2014C>T is a nonsense mutation that leads to an early termination signal at Gln672  triggering either NMD or producing a 27% truncated protein. Cilia show nearly complete immotility and stiffness consistent with PCD.

This variant was downscored to 1 for homozygosity.  Further downscored to 0.5 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a heterogeneous disease with a diverse clinical and genetic spectrum among populations worldwide. Few cases of pediatric PCD have been reported from China.
dc:source.dc:creator: Guan Y
dc:source.dc:title: Clinical and Genetic Spectrum of Children With Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia in China.

evidence.dc:description: NM_003114.5(SPAG1):c.2542del is a frameshift mutation that replaces Asp848 with Ile and a premature termination sequence 10aa downstream. This variant is predicted to truncate 8% of the protein.

This variant has been downscored to 0.5 for homozygosity and consanguinity. It has been further down scored to 0.25 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out. It has been further downscored to 0.1 because of the mutation's proximity to the C-terminus and because because no data was available to show paternal or maternal segregation of the mutant allele.

evidence.dc:description: NM_003114.5(SPAG1):c.679G>T is a nonsense mutation predicted to replace Glu227 with a termination signal, either triggering nonsense-mediated RNA decay (NMD) or truncating 75% of the protein Immunofluorescent analysis of DNAH5 and DNAL1 in respiratory cells from a control and this PCD patient show that DNAH5 (outer dynein arm marker) and DNALI1 (inner dynein arm marker) are missing from the ciliary axoneme of the PCD patient.  The absence of these dyneins in the axonemes is consistent with a defective SPAG1 unable to fulfill its normal role in the assembly of dynein arms.

This variant was downscored to 1 for homozygosity. This variant was further downscored to 0.5 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

evidence.detectionMethod: For those cases with available family members for segregation analysis, phase was determined to be trans.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Molecular genetic analysis (Sanger sequencing) was conducted on the following known PCD genes: DNAH5, DNAI1, CCDC39, CCDC40, DNAI2, DNAH11, RSPH9, RSPH4A, DNAAF1, DNAAF2, TXNDC3, DNAL1 (Kim et al., 2014 PMID:24498942). SPAG 1 was not included in these genetic tests, hence no pathogenic variant was found for this proband.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is an autosomal-recessive disorder resulting from loss of normal ciliary function. Symptoms include neonatal respiratory distress, chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus, and infertility. Clinical features may be subtle and highly variable, making the diagnosis of PCD challenging. The diagnosis can be confirmed with ciliary ultrastructure analysis and/or molecular genetic testing of 32 PCD-associated genes. However, because of this genetic heterogeneity, comprehensive molecular genetic testing is not considered the standard of care, and the most efficient molecular approach has yet to be elucidated. Here, we propose a cost-effective and time-efficient molecular genetic algorithm to solve cases of PCD. We conducted targeted copy number variation (CNV) analysis and/or whole-exome sequencing on 20 families (22 patients) from a subset of 45 families (52 patients) with a clinical diagnosis of PCD who did not have a molecular genetic diagnosis after Sanger sequencing of 12 PCD-associated genes. This combined molecular genetic approach led to the identification of 4 of 20 (20%) families with clinically significant CNVs and 7 of 20 (35%) families with biallelic pathogenic mutations in recently identified PCD genes, resulting in an increased molecular genetic diagnostic rate of 55% (11/20). In patients with a clinical diagnosis of PCD, whole-exome sequencing followed by targeted CNV analysis results in an overall molecular genetic yield of 76% (34/45).
dc:source.dc:creator: Marshall CR
dc:source.dc:title: Whole-Exome Sequencing and Targeted Copy Number Analysis in Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia.

evidence.dc:description: NM_003114.5(SPAG1):c.1519dup is a frameshift mutation that replaces Ile507 with Asn and a termination signal 5 amino acids downstream, either leading to NMD or producing a 45% truncated protein.
Downscored to 1 because of homozygosity. Downscored to 0.75 for lack of segregation information.

evidence.detectionMethod: Candidiate variants were confirmed by PCR amplification followed by Sanger sequencing. Segregation analysis revealed that genetic variants were inherited in trans.

evidence.rdfs:label: UNC-1231 II-1

evidence.dc:description: NC_000008.11:g.100213079C>G is a splicing mutation in intron 10 of the SPAG1 gene but has been scored as a null mutation because the authors were able to RT-PCR and sequence a transcript from this variant allele that suggests this is a null mutation.  This transcript contains a 10 nucleotide insertion at the start of exon 11 that corresponds to 10 nucleotides from intron 10 immediately downstream of the variation, suggesting that this C>G substitution shifts the exon 11 splice donor site ten nucleotides upstream, leading to a premature stop codon at the start of exon 12 (p.Lys336Ilefs119). This alteration replaces Lys336 with Ile and a termination signal 119 amino acids downstream, either leading to NMD or producing a 64% truncated protein. (See experimental data section for more information on SPAG1 isoforms seen in this individual.)

Downscored for homozygosity. This variant was further downscored to 0.5 because this variant was identified by single-gene Sanger sequencing. PCD is a genetically heterogeneous disease and other genetic etiologies that could lead to a similar phenotype have not been ruled out.

dc:description:
Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetically heterogeneous group of disorders, usually beginning in early childhood, characterized by chronic cough, recurrent infections of the upper and lower respiratory tract, randomization of left/right body asymmetry, and subfertility (PMID: 32943623). The PCD phenotype results from structural and/or functional abnormalities of motile cilia and flagella. Ciliary motility is powered by a set of axoneme-specific dynein motor complexes. These large multiprotein complexes are assembled within the cytoplasm by dynein axonemal assembly factors (DNAAFs) before their transport into cilia. Mutations in genes encoding DNAAFs result in the improper cytoplasmic preassembly of dynein chains, causing defects in both inner (IDA) and outer dynein arms (ODA) that can result in cilia immotility (PMID: 31624012). 

SPAG1 (Sperm Associated Antigen 1) was initially identified and characterized as a human testis-specific protein related to female infertility and spermatogenesis (PMIDs: 1299558, 11517287) and was later also identified as a marker of pancreatic cancer progression and proposed to promote motility of cancer cells (PMID: 16983343). The *SPAG1* (*DNAAF13*) gene was first reported in relation to PCD by Knowles et al. in 2013 when whole exome sequencing identified *SPAG1* biallelic variants in individuals with PCD and defective ODAs and IDAs (PMID: 24055112). This study also showed that *SPAG1* was expressed in human airway epithelial cells and it was proposed that SPAG1 plays a role in the cytoplasmic preassembly of IDAs and ODAs. The specific disease entity, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 28 is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the *SPAG1* gene. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found the molecular mechanism and autosomal recessive mode of inheritance to be consistent among unrelated patients, while the phenotypic variability among them appeared to represent a spectrum of disease rather than separate disease entities. Therefore, cases caused by inherited *SPAG1* variants have been lumped into a single disease entity, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 28 (MONDO: 0014216, OMIM # 615505).

Evidence from 16 probands in 5 publications have been included in this curation representing 13 unique variants (1 missense, 3 nonsense, 7 frameshift, 1 splice site, and 1 large deletion) (PMIDs: 24055112, 32502479, 33577779, 26139845, 35178554). Of note, three of these variants have been identified as founder mutations by haplotype analysis: NM_003114.5:c.902_906del (p.Lys301fs), Clin Var ID:209000; NM_003114.5:c.2014C>T (p.Gln672Ter), ClinVar ID: 88683; and NC_000008.11:g.100151617_100163589del, Clin Var ID:88681 (PMID: 24055112). These founder mutations are seen in multiple studies (PMIDs: 24055112, 35178554, 26228299) and are seen repeatedly in this curation. Five of the probands in this curation carry NC_000008.11:g.100151617_100163589del; two carry NM_003114.5:c.902_906del; and 6 carry NM_003114.5:c.2014C>T. The mechanism of pathogenicity in *SPAG1* mutations appears to be biallelic loss of function. There is additional case-level evidence available in the literature, but its inclusion in this curation was not necessary to reach the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points).

The gene-disease relationship between *SPAG1* and PCD 28 is supported by protein expression data. Immunoblot analysis shows expression of full length SPAG1 in healthy differentiated respiratory epithelial whole cell lysates but not in ciliary axonemes or undifferentiated respiratory epithelial cell lysates (PMID: 24055112). This pattern is consistent with a role of full length SPAG1 in the cytoplasmic preassembly of dynein arm complexes in the respiratory epithelial cell. More recent studies show that full length SPAG1 is absent in respiratory epithelial cells of three PCD patients with biallelic *SPAG1* mutations, but present in control samples (PMID: 35178554). The absence of full length SPAG1 is consistent with the absence of ODAs and IDAs and ciliary immotility in most PCD patients with *SPAG1* mutations, strengthening the *SPAG1*-PCD 28 gene-disease association.

Of note, at least three major isoforms of SPAG1 have been described in human respiratory epithelial cells: a full length 926 amino acid (~106-kDa) protein, a 416 amino acid (~94-kDa) protein product of alternative splicing (containing first 10 exons), and a 545 amino acid (~60-kDa) protein product of an alternative in-frame start codon (starts at pMet382 and contains exons 11-19) (PMIDs: 16983343, 24055112, 35178554). The role these alternative isoforms might play in the preassembly of dynein arms is still not well understood. Transmission electron microscopy of cilia cross sections from respiratory epithelial cells of two of the three patients presented by Smith et al 2022 (PMID: 35178554) have an atypical *SPAG1* PCD ultrastructural phenotype with no IDAs but some normal ODAs and HSVM shows residual ciliary motility. Immunolocalization studies to further characterize cilia structure in the cells of these patients showed an absence of DNAH5 and DNAI1 (ODA proteins) and an absence of the DNALI1 (IDA protein) in the patient with typical PCD ultrastructure, while the two atypical phenotype patients had no DNALI1 staining of the IDAs but still had DNAI1 and DNAH5 present along the full length of the ciliary axoneme  (albeit at a reduced level compared to control cilia) confirming the absence of IDAs and the presence of ODAs. These two patients retain expression of the 60-kDa isoform while the other patient (lacking ODAs and IDAs, no ciliary motility) does not. These authors propose that the SPAG1 60-kDA isomer may be able to compensate for a lack of full length SPAG1 by assembling some normal ODAs. While the 106-kDa and 94-kDa isoforms are expressed specifically during ciliogenesis, the 60-kDa isoform is constitutively expressed, suggesting that the 60-kDA isoform may play a motile cilia-independent function in normal epithelium.
  
The cytoplasmic folding and preassembly of dynein arm proteins into larger complexes takes place in a stepwise manner involving interactions with various DNAAFs, chaperones, and co-chaperones (PMID: 31817850). SPAG1 has been hypothesized to be one of many DNAAFs that interact to form dynein arm complexes in ciliated cells (PMID: 30561330). Immunoprecipitation of SPAG1 using SPAG1 antibody shows that SPAG1 interacts with dynein chains DNAH6 and DNAH5. SPAG1 also co-precipitates with co-chaperone complex proteins RPAP3, RUVBL1, and RUVBL2 as well as other DNAAFs: DNAAF1, DNAAF2, DNAAF3, DNAAF10 (WDR92), and DNAAF15 (PIH1D2). DNAAF1, DNAAF2, and DNAAF3 are DNAAFs that have been previously associated with PCD (PMID: 32943623). DNAAF10, RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 are components of the R2TP/Prefoldin-like complex, an HSP90 co-chaperone complex involved in the assembly process of many molecular machines. These protein interactions identified by immunoprecipitation are consistent with SPAG1's involvement in axonemal dynein arm assembly. The interaction of SPAG1 with a large co-chaperone complex has also been confirmed by Chagot et al 2019 (PMID: 31118266) who used NMR and molecular dynamics simulations to characterize the molecular level structure and dynamics of SPAG1 in complex (via its TPR domains) with the tail of HSP70 and HSP90. SPAG1 was shown to be part of the R2SP co-chaperone complex, which combines SPAG1, PIH1D2, RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 proteins to work with protein chaperones HSP70 and HSP90 in the quaternary preassembly of dynein arm protein complexes.

Two animal models have been used to support the gene-disease relationship between *SPAG1* and PCD 28. Morpholino knockdown of *spag1* in zebrafish embryos produced zebrafish exhibiting dorsal body axis curvature and hydrocephalus (PMID: 24055112). Zebrafish have motile cilia in the left-right organizer (Kupffer's vesicle), the spinal canal, pronephric ducts, brain ventricles, and olfactory placode. The defects seen in zebrafish when *spag1* is knocked down using morpholinos are consistent with the phenotype one might see in zebrafish with defective motile cilia (hydrocephalus, curved axis), however there were non-significant laterality defects and cilia function was not tested. RNAi knockdown of *Drosophila CG18472/Spag1* produces flies with loss of both ODAs and IDAs. Male infertility, immotile sperm, the loss of auditory/vibration mechanotransduction in Ch neurons (impaired larval hearing), and defective adult proprioception in SPAG1 depleted *Drosophila* mutants are phenotypes consistent with ciliary/flagellar immotility and in line with human *SPAG1* mutation ciliary phenotypes.

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting a gene-disease relationship between variants in *SPAG1* and Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 28. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on June, 15, 2022 (SOP Version 8).
